ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read a narrative book called A Fire Truck Named Red. We learned about the ways that Red and Papa helped their community.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of different vehicles that are important in our communities.
Let’s look at the first picture together. What do you see? Is this vehicle in your community? How is this vehicle important?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.
Talk About Helpers Help children identify the community helpers who drive these vehicles (e.g., police officer, sanitation worker, doctor, construction worker, etc.)
If children respond with a phrase, have them repeat a complete sentence after you.

Challenge children to use what they know about their community to make inferences about how each of the vehicles in the picture cards helps their community. Ask, What does an ambulance do? How does it help a community?

Children whose first language is Spanish will recognize the Spanish cognate vehículo for the English word vehicle. Help children make this connection as well as the connection between ambulancia and ambulance.
Allow children to draw a response to each question using colored pencils, crayons, or markers. Then have children share their drawings and talk about what they drew.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story A Fire Truck Named Red and learned about taking another perspective. Rowan learned to take his grandfather’s perspective about Red. He learned that, like his grandfather, he and Red could make a great team.
When we take another perspective, we learn to think about how someone else sees or feels something.
Today we will look at pictures of children and try to figure out their perspectives, or points of view.
Let’s look at the first picture together. What do you see? Is the ball closer to the boy or to the girl? How can we take the boy’s perspective? How can we take the girl’s perspective?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

Talk About It Ask children to brainstorm other points of view. For example, when they stand in a line, being at the front of the line is a different perspective than being at the back of the line. Have children explain how those two perspectives are different. Ask, Why is it important to know that those two perspectives are different?
Before asking children to identify a perspective, make sure that they fully understand its meaning. Use words like “point of view” or “what he or she sees” to help provide support.
Select cards at random and have children compare the perspectives of the people in the photos. Are they the same? Are they different?

Allow children to respond to the questions with a physical response. For example, if a picture card shows a person going down on a seesaw, they might crouch down and sit on the floor. If it shows a person going up on a seesaw, they might stand up on their toes. Physical and visual clues like these can help language learners participate in small-group activities as their language skills develop.

Some children may have difficulty identifying perspectives. If so, have children try acting out the perspective. For example, have two children stand apart from one another and have one child hold a ball. Ask children to identify the child that is closer to the ball and then the child that is farther away from the ball.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we learned that whenever Papa and Red got a call to help, they rushed to the scene. What scenes did they rush to? The word scene is a place where something happens, like a blaze or a cat that needs rescuing. Police officers and firefighters often rush to a scene. We can also use the word scene to talk about a place that we see in a book or in a picture.
Today we will look at pictures with different scenes. We will decide where the scene of each one is.
Let’s look at the first picture together. What do you see? Is this a scene, or place, that you have been to before?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

Talk About It Ask children to name things that are always in a classroom. Explain that scenes can vary from place to place. How a place looks in one community can look different in another community. Have children describe a scene in their neighborhood.
Check children’s understanding of the word scene before you ask each question. Ask children to describe what they see in the picture.
Go around and ask children to choose a picture card that is a place they like to go. Have them explain why they chose that card.

Multilingual learners may need to review community-related words before answering the questions. Refer to page 20 of the book to show the scene with the fire station. Explain that a fire station is a place where fire trucks, like Red, are kept.

Allow children to draw a response to each question using colored pencils, crayons, or markers. Then have children share their drawings and talk about what they drew. For example, they might draw books on a shelf to depict a library, or a swingset to depict a park.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read The Wheels on the Bus poster and learned about different vehicles. We learned that many, but not all, vehicles have engines. Some vehicles have wings.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of different vehicles, talk about how they help us, and sort them into two groups:

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: Land Vehicles is for vehicles that run on the land.
Not Land Vehicles is for vehicles that do not run on the land. We’ll discuss where these vehicles run.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Let’s look at the first picture together. What do you see? What kind of vehicle is this? Does this vehicle travel on land? Where does it travel? That’s right. It travels on water.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

Talk About Vehicles Ask children to name other vehicles that travel on land, on the water, and in the air. Ask children to name the vehicles they have been on. Which vehicle would they most like to go on? Which one is their favorite?

Show children three picture cards at a time, where one is an example and the other two are not (e.g., two land vehicles and one water vehicle). Ask: Which one doesn’t belong? Then ask: How do you know? Repeat with other groups of three cards.
Ask children to review the pictures and identify vehicles that have wheels. Then have children identify vehicles that do not have wheels.

Check multilingual learners’ knowledge of the names for an ambulance, a helicopter, a canoe, and a train. Some Spanish speakers may use the same word (barco) for a canoe, a ship, and a boat. Show children pictures of canoes, ships, and boats to differentiate the vehicles.

Discuss different objects that have volume control such as a television or a car radio. Explain that when we quiet down, we turn down our volume. Have children make the sound of a siren in a loud voice and then a quiet voice. Talk about times when it is okay to speak loudly and when it is important to turn down the volume and speak in a quiet voice. Encourage children to use the word volume to discuss how they make their voices louder and quieter.
